meta.title: Q2 2013 Earnings Call - UK and South Africa

participant.affiliation: Chief Executive Officer-Non Ferrous Business, BHP Billiton Ltd.
Chief Financial Officer, BHP Billiton Ltd.
SG Asia Holdings India Pvt Ltd.

plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, I am now handing you over to the host of today's call, BHP Billiton's Chief Executive Officer, Marius Kloppers.

Thank you. Ladies and gentlemen, good morning. Welcome to our teleconference that follows the release of our December 2012 interim results. My apologies that at the half year, the time zones just make it very difficult for us to cover both time zones at the same time.

I'm speaking to you from Sydney, and Graham Kerr, our CFO, is in London, and I would also like to welcome Andrew MacKenzie who is here with me in Sydney, and I'd like to again congratulate him on his election. I will talk a little bit about Andrew's election in due course, but would, in the first instance, like to just recap and summarize the presentation that I made this morning.

We believe that we've had strong results in what has been a more challenging environment overall for the industry. We are delivering on commitments that we've made. We've had strong and predictable results, and in particular, we want to reaffirm our previous production guidance. We would like to profile as the ones that noticed the changing environment first, and we'd like to present today $1.9 billion of controllable cash cost savings, which is the start of a cost reduction program underpinned by having started earlier than our peer group. Our major projects remain on schedule and budget. We've continued to simplify an already simple portfolio and we have a positive outlook for the business.

With regards to financial performance, the first half of our financial year was characterized by slowing growth and at some times, anxiety over where China was heading. Prices were volatile and currencies, our producer currencies were strong. The offsets that we were able to achieve in terms of cost savings were not enough to outweigh the negative impact of the reduced price and increased producer currencies.

Nevertheless, we've had strong results. Underlying EBITDA declined by 29% to $13.2 billion, underlying EBIT by 38% to $9.8 billion, and attributable profit by 58% to $4.2 billion. And that number is inclusive of exceptional items totaling $1.4 billion. And we have a good run on getting good prices in our portfolio simplification with $4.3 billion of divestments either announced or completed at prices above what the market ascribes to the assets that were being marketing.
Like our production guidance, our capital and exploration expenditure of $12.2 billion in the half was exactly on plan. Our full year guidance is again unchanged at $22 billion.

Our 20 projects are all on schedule and budget. There is no change in the guidance that the majority of them will come on production before the end of our 2015 financial year. And gearing remains within the parameters of our single A – strong single A rating. And we've declared an interim dividend of $0.57 per share, extending the unbroken track record of our progressive dividend.

So the overall message on the half is that we had price that was not supported, currencies that were not supported. Nevertheless, we were able to affect some offsets by cost savings and volume increases, and we've performed well on those things that we can control: safety, volume and costs.

Let me just then say a few words on succession and once again congratulate Andrew. Obviously, we feel proud of the long-term approach we take to leadership development and succession. It's a very, very important job. In that context, my preparation and the team for eventual succession started five and a half years ago. I recruited Andrew virtually on day one, took a little bit a persuasion. And in that period that has past, (04:52) we've made some portfolio changes to the various team members in order to stretch and develop them fully. We've brought on some supernumerary members a year or so – a little over a year ago in order to, again, take the next step in succession. And today, we've completed that process.

I met Andrew in a joint venture context. I gave him a call following a very positive interaction on that joint venture issue that we were trying to solve. I gave him a call almost as soon as I became CEO. He trusted me enough to say yes, and then went on to go set our 12 month (05:43). So there's a really deep relationship here.

Andrew has run the non-ferrous business with aplomb and has got distinguishment in that he has got such deep experience in both the oil and gas and minerals experience. So, I will invite Andrew to make a few comments towards the end of this discussion. But I think that it's appropriate that at this point in time we move to questions. If you could as always state your name and then address the questions to me in the first instance, I will pass some of them to Graham as appropriate.
So, operator, can I have the first question, please?
Yes, certainly. And your first question today comes from the line of Jason Fairclough from Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Jason, please go ahead.
Hi, good morning, gentlemen. And first, I did want to congratulate Andrew on his appointment, and Marius, best of luck to you in your future endeavors. Two quick questions.
Thank you, Jason.
Thank you, Jason.

Just two quick ones from me. First on Jansen, it doesn't get much mention today in the release, save for the fact that construction of the shafts is underway and the project still does remain subject to board approval. I guess I'm left wondering, how much money can you spend on a project that isn't board-approved?

And then the second question would be for Andrew. I guess given that -- your background at BP, could you give some thoughts on BHP strategy for oil and gas and whether at the margin you might think about tweaking that? And specifically I'm thinking about the mix in capital allocation here between offshore and then onshore U.S.

Yes, Jason, we're not going to give Andrew any strategic questions today. There is ample opportunity for that, but the purpose of this call is to cover the results. Andy will make a few comments at the end, and obviously, we will be doing the rounds just (07:48).

On Jansen, the reason that's relatively underemphasized is that there is no imminent approval. We are going to go through full year results before that project is slated to be approved. I can confirm that technically the process is – project is tracking very well. And there is no update on the approvals and the preapprovals that we've given previously. We are tracking within the envelope of the approvals that we've made before.
So apologies for not...
No. That's fine.
...being able to turn this into a Q&A session for Andrew specifically today.
Understood. All right. Many thanks.
Thank you.
Can we have the next question, please?
The next question today comes from the line of Kieran Daly of Macquarie. Kieran, please go ahead.

Thanks. Yes, good morning and I just reiterate those congratulations all around as well. And my – it's quite clear from the presentation that copper is obviously a very much preferred commodity of BHP's in the medium to long term. Now, you obviously Escondida is a key part of that strategy in the short to medium term with getting back up to 1.3 million tons. And if Olympic Dam doesn't get the approval, and it's obviously a long lead time project in any case, it looks like you've got a bit of a gap in your portfolio in terms of copper growth in that medium to long term, in the absence of Olympic Dam. How do you think about that? Would you agree with that comment? What are you guys doing perhaps to fill that apparent gap in the portfolio?

And then the second question is – you talked a lot about, in the presentation, about copper, iron ore, aluminium and so on, and it's quite clear aluminium and nickel are obviously non-core. But two commodities that sort of drop to the bottom of the list, are manganese and thermal coal. And I just wonder if you could just remind us of your strategic thinking about those two commodities in terms of your portfolio.

Thank you, Kieran. In terms of copper, I'd probably first comment that we've still got a project that is being ramped up because we are full in as much as we can at this stage execute. And that's obviously the Spence Hypogene project. And we forget that that is a very material project that is waiting there and obviously then the Escondida projects.

And then, what is now I think, from memory, (10:31) the world's third largest copper mine, which is Antamina, the expansion sequence there is continuing. So, I think we shouldn't underestimate the potential of the core ore bodies that they've still got ahead of them for incremental expansions. However, Andrew's exploration program that he has running now obviously will continue to run in a different sense, has been almost wholly focused on copper and will continue to be focused on copper.

In terms of manganese and thermal coal, manganese is a joint venture with Anglo American, so obviously there are a different set of foundry conditions on the two assets, Australia, South Africa that we run there. Not something we have announced any imminent plans.

On thermal coal, I think on balance, we see that a little bit the same as the iron ore business where at some point in time, the thermal coal markets plateau and decline. And therefore, the marching orders for the thermal coal people is to maximize the value of their current asset set, notably by investments in (11:48) energy coal.

I think on balance, we should see over time, some of the smaller coal mines or coal properties within the portfolio continue the rationalization path that we've been on for basically the last 10 years. And you've seen that most recently with the Navajo mine sale that we're contemplating in – or busy executing in New Mexico. And you should see, Kieran, I think on balance, thermal coal over time, continue to play a smaller role in the overall product mix.
But just going back to manganese, Marius, in terms of the commodity itself, how do see that commodity in terms of the supply/demand fundamentals going forward?

Kieran, not as brief on most recent things, but generally, we view that as a business with slightly lower barriers to entry than some of our other businesses, but a business in which we own the definitive profit generating asset in GEMCO. And that really is, in our mind, going to continue to be the mainstay of the earnings. And we probably feel that the Australian asset – sorry, the South African assets will continue to be constrained through power and rail allocations, so not a lot of growth envisaged in particular in that part of the portfolio, nor, however, have we got any rationalization plans at this stage that have been announced.
Okay, thanks very much, Marius.
Thank you. And today's next question comes from the line of Sam Catalano of Nomura. Sam, your line is open.

Hi, good evening, Marius. Two questions. You've mentioned, I guess BHP a year ago as at the forefront of the change in focus with regards to pushing capital efficiency, cost cutting and these sorts of measures. At some point -- it's obviously been reflected in many of your peers over the last 12 months also. So at some point in the future, acquisitions or accelerating some of that capital becomes potentially benefits to a first mover in that sort of environment as well. What signs would BHP look for to potentially slightly alter in terms of the approach towards that?

Sam, I think for now, our guidance is unchanged to what we had when I last discussed with you, that on balance, we see CapEx trending downwards next year. We would like to – not that we're uncomfortable with our gearing level, but on balance, we would like to pay down our capital to a certain extent – I mean, pay down debt to a certain extent.

And I think that as you engage with Andrew going forward, I think that you will hear him say that he has got an even sharper focus on the assets in the portfolio. So all in all, we probably feel that we've got plenty to chew on. We're probably at capacity in terms of what we can execute, both in terms of workload and balance sheet and we probably feel that the 10% growth rate, which we will have over the next – this year and next, is higher than the trend growth which we'd previously indicated as somewhere in the order of 5%.
Thanks, Marius.
And your next question today comes from the line of Menno Sanderse from Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead with your question.

Yes, good morning. It's Menno at Morgan Stanley, just a quick question on met coal. You had a weak first half in terms of earnings despite the ramp-up in volumes. Is the company taking additional cost measures in the next six to 12 months to try and rectify that? And secondly, are you seeing any change in vibes (15:53) from the Australian government with respect to expectation (15:56) which you mentioned earlier today as being one of the culprits of the poor results?

So I think let's first talk about the structural costs that we've added to grow to the royalty cost (16:06). I think we've had, from memory, between carbon taxes and greater royalties and some others tweaks and adjustments in what we pay government tariff, on the order of $18 of cost increase – structural cost increase per ton given our product mix. Those costs are just an additional end cost (16:27).

If we look at the freight – sorry, the start-up related costs and the volume constrained-related costs, we are seeing the progress there being very rapid in reversing those trends. And then I would point you to one line in the full transcript, which is posted on our Web site, which specifically notes that we expect in the second half progress in the met coal business. And there is also a comment from me that says we have every expectation that this business is going to be a good business at today's prices, given what we're seeing.
I should also note that the position we were in for the first half is exactly to the guidance that we gave before. There is no surprise in the result that we declared today.
Thanks.
Thank you, Menno.
Thank you. And the next question comes from the line of Rob Clifford of Deutsche Bank. Rob, please go ahead.
Hey, Rob.

Hey, good evening, gents. I've got two questions, firstly, just on CapEx of $12 billion, operating costs closed at $6 billion, so it's pretty difficult for your operations to live within their means this period. What timeframe are you expecting to be able to make those two meet, so the operations live within their means?

And the second, just on Navajo Coal, I know it's reasonably small but the potential transfer of that, the thinking behind that, is that to do with indigenization or is it a comment on your view on U.S. coal or is there some deal to be done around your partnership with Resolution in there as well?

Navajo Coal basically is a business where given the trajectory that the U.S. coal business is on already delivers the majority of the value by way of royalty to the Navajo nation. And what we're actually doing here is we're selling the residual that we have in the mine and putting all of the economic rent in one set of hands, for which it's a very worthwhile exercise to do.

It's probably a little subscale in terms of an operation to run for us for the Navajo, which make up 85% of the workforce, from memory. This is clearly a different issue. But it is – the value there is related to the future of coal generation, the future of renewal of coal generation permits and the future of the growth in coal generation in the U.S. that are all constrained.

It's got nothing to do with any other aspect of the business, but the fact that it's dropped below scale (19:15) level and that there is a logical internalizer of the residual value that we still hold there.

In terms of CapEx, no change from what we said last time. Obviously, with the speed with which prices have come on – come off, and the fact that the average project lasts for three or four years, if you've got a very dramatic price change such as we've seen, you're not going to shut down project – good projects in execution to get to a live-within-your-means situation in any given year.

However, I have every expectation that as we go forward over the next year or two, we are going to, all else being equal, target a budgeting cycle this year, which we normally do, a detailed two-year budget, which has as a base case, getting to a breakeven or slightly reducing of the debt levels on the balance sheet in that plan. And that's more or less the broad planning parameters.
Okay. Thanks for that. And best of luck to you both.
Thank you.
Thanks, Rob.
Thank you. And today's next question comes from Amos Fletcher of Barclays. Please go ahead.

Yes. Good morning. I just had two questions, firstly on the cash flow side. I noticed you had a $1.2 billion build in working capital despite commodity prices generally falling during the period. And also your cash tax bill of $4.3 billion was materially higher than the P&L charge. I was wondering if you could explain the reasons behind that?
And my second question is just are you prepared to put a number on a cost cutting target over the next year or two? Thanks.

Yes. Let me answer the second part first. We said that we would like to keep our costs, firstly, flat in U.S.-denominated cash cost per copper unit. We have achieved that excluding restructuring costs, which we have transparently outlined today. Our unit, U.S. dollar cash cost was down about 2.5%. Obviously we would like to go further and again, as you guys engage with Andrew, I'm sure that you're going to hear how he is going to continue to engage on that target – sorry, on that endeavor.

Our approach here is traceable savings. So, we want to give you a methodology to trace it off a given base, which is what we tried to do today and we'd like to focus on delivered results as opposed to putting a big target out there. Our approach is also, in the third instance, to exclude costs that are largely not in our control from that target, for example, royalties and energy, even though those effects this past were favorable for us and would have pushed the $1.9 billion to $2.2 billion or $2.3 billion, from memory, because essentially we don't control them.

So, we are laser-focused on getting the controllable costs down. And obviously what you've seen here is that we've kept business development costs, exploration costs, consistent with the fact that we (23:03) portfolio. You've seen the comment that we have already removed, in crude terms, bums on seats, 20% of all of the overhead that we carried 12 months ago.

So, we push on. Obviously, now comes the next phase of the cost savings, which is to have the reduced personnel application that we've got following those reductions flow through a full half of costs. Obviously, we were cutting gearing in the half so on a run rate basis we're there, but we'll see the first impact of that in the next half. And then continue to do two more things: one, attack the fixed cost base; and two, dilute the fixed cost base as we ramp up the production of the businesses.

In terms of the taxable, your tax payments on a cash basis always lag your receipts. So in a falling market what you're doing is you're paying tax of the higher revenues of the previous six months, roughly speaking. So, on the detailed drill in into the working capital, made – which are once-off in nature, perhaps I can ask Graham to just quickly give us a rundown and a drawdown on that. Graham if you may?

Certainly can, Marius. Probably when we talk about the tax – we'll come back to the working capital – two aspects on the tax, there is certainly the aspect in terms of the timing of the payment, and the payment related to when we're making more profit in the corresponding period. But, I think the second thing to note in this period, we obviously had a number of exceptions that we spoke about that basically are coming from the tax expense number and have lowered the tax expense number on the P&L. So that drives the primary difference between tax paid and what we're actually showing on the P&L for the period.

The second question that was around working capital, really it reflects $1 billion in terms of time of inventory, and also creditors. And to be honest, that's just really timing that we expect to unwind over the next period. So nothing structurally different.

Graham, if I may just add, what Mike Henry is targeting is a fall (25:49) on the revenue side of the business, a reduction in the days of credit extended and a reduction in the physical inventories. And tracking his progress, we believe it's to plan. Please understand, though, that given the large lumpy nature of our CapEx programs, the amount of working capital that you've got tied up at any snapshot in time, varies quite a bit. But if I look at the underlying overdues, receivables, and so on in the company, I think what you're looking at it is a once-off effect here and we're going to give that – we're going to apply every power that we have to get that cash back.
Okay. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Amos.
Thank you. And today's next question comes from the line of Peter Davey of Standard Bank. Peter, please go ahead.
Hi, Peter. How are you?

I'm very well, Marius. Thank you very much. Parts of my questions have already been answered but maybe just to sort of follow on, is the cost – two parts. The cost savings, is the just under $2 billion annualized cost savings, is that your ultimate target or is there a higher one that can be achievable? And the second part is, given that the met coal industry is suffering from the current prices, if prices stay at these levels for the next couple of years, what do you see as the main response there by the industry?
Let me pass the first part of that question to Graham and let me ask -- then answer, when he's completed that I'll talk a little bit about met coal.

Thanks, Marius. Peter, I mean, to answer your question on costs, I mean what we're really focused on as part of this results presentation is being very clear on focusing on actual results, and being very clear on focusing on transparency. And as you rightly point out, for the period we had a $944 million saving in what we call controllable cash cost savings. On an annualized basis, that is $1.9 billion. That's predominantly made up of operating efficiencies, reduction in overheads and we're also reducing our exploration and business development costs – sorry, exploration and business development costs.

As Marius alluded to in his speech last night, I mean the focus this year has almost been on – been the, basically on normalizing our costs, it's -- now the focus going forward is basically how do we reduce that cost going further. So, while we're not certainly committed to targets in terms of publicly, you should expect us to continue to move in that space and drive down our costs. But what we're being very clear about as part of this results presentation is telling you what we've done today rather than focusing on aspirational targets.
But the trend going forward is to basically bend the trend and continue the rage on costs.

And then on the met coal question, I think, perhaps two comments, demand is very dependent on met coal imports in China. And that will be a large determinant of the overall supply/demand balance. Second part is perhaps in terms of our cost structures, we were not as impacted as much as some of the other Australian producers by the recent trends. And so, we feel that we're in reasonably good shape there. And I think that just if I can reiterate our own push here in our met coal business is just very, very hard on costs and we should see some considerable impact there over the next six months.

As to the broader industry, probably I think that the Australian industry, particularly those players with weaker quality of coking coal, we believe is going to continue to remain under pressure, as is the broader Australian energy coal industry, unless the exchange rate moves here, which doesn't seem that likely at the moment. Thank you, Peter.
Thanks, Marius.
Thank you. And the next question today comes from the line of Sylvain Brunet from Exane BNP Paribas. Please go ahead.

Good evening, Marius. Good morning, Andrew and congratulations for the new role and congratulations, Marius for your tenure during these volatile years. Three questions, if I may. First one was related to a couple of market comments around disposals, potentially the Gregory complex and also the Pinto Valley in copper, if you could maybe comment there.
Second one, which is more of an accounting one, would you say at this point there is still a risk of a further write-down in your shale assets depending on the methodology you're using?
And lastly, I was wondering in your fairly cautious view on the iron ore outlook, where does India picture in the near term? I think you had more positive comments on that lately. Thank you.

Sorry, no updates on Gregory and Pinto Valley. Obviously, we've made some filings which have been picked up by the media and interpreted. We're looking for value in those assets. If we get value, we will act. If we don't get value, we don't, in line with the approach on the other assets.

On gas, obviously, we believe that we've done our homework. We've just reappraised those assets and now, I should point that the price of gas when we did the – the impairment was considerably lower than the price now, so obviously, any like-for-like comparison now would give actually a unbalanced or higher value than the value that we calculated at the time that the impairments were made.

Now, on iron ore, I think without wanting to speculate on price, we probably have on the order of about half GDP growth rate in China flowing through pig iron demand. That equates to, let's call it, 4% also of steel growth this year, maybe 3-1/2% in China, on the order of 60 million tons or so of incremental iron ore needed, probably 100 million tons or so being delivered.

If the plans, which are reasonably advanced, go through, those tons are predominantly backend loaded, so I think I can understand why the market is saying that the iron ore price will be firm upfront and weaker at the back end of the year. And we probably don't question the way that the market is backwardating that price at the moment. Thank you.
Thanks, Marius.
Thank you. And your next question today, Marius, comes from the line of Myles Allsop of UBS.
Thanks, guys.
Myles.

I have three quick questions as well if I may. Just in terms of the succession planning, Marius, you seem too young to retire. But just looking back over the last few years, what do you see as your greatest achievement, what do you regret most and what advice would you give to Andrew? And then secondly, just on the expiration of spending cuts, is that going to impact gross longer term or do you just believe that some of these geologists have got overzealous with spending over the last few years and it just needs to be reined in and it will not impact growth? And just on the cost cutting as well...

We perhaps just got to stop there. I'm going to lose track of all of the questions. So, let me just try and answer that. Yes, I'm leaving because clearly Andrew has given me all of the advice that he had to impart. I think that Andrew has been a part of every decision that's been made here. I have really no parting quotes of wisdom here. We've had five years to equalize the databases between the two of us on our thoughts.

On the – what has changed, I think that we've got a more productive relationship between buyers and sellers in the iron ore business, at the same time as giving sellers, which have the information asymmetry here, a more clear class for their product. That's a pretty profound change, which again, I wouldn't take credit for, the marketers did that. But it did happen in the last five years.

We comprehensively outperformed our peer group. Again, I don't think that it's ascribable to me nor is it in full ascribable to the team or teams. A lot of it goes back to the people that left us the legacy. But we did have a not perfect decision making, but clearly better decision making than our peers, if we look at the total shareholder return in particular.

For me, lastly, I cannot have any conversation about performance without talking about safety. 20% reduction in greenhouse gas, almost a 40% reduction in injury rates and certainly from a decade or so ago, about a 75% reduction in fatalities. Those things don't come without better accountability, better sustainability – sorry, better standardization of process and better planning and execution. Again, I suspect that you're going to hear Andrew say a lot about that going forward.

Next point on exploration. Most of our exploration spend on the minerals side is actually brownfield exploration. These are the types of drilling that we do around the existing ore bodies in order to bring minerals that are in inventory into a readily exploitable form. Clearly, we've slowed down the rate of CapEx growth, therefore you can slow down as a knock-on effect, the rate at which you mature the tenement. That is the main impact on the exploration spend and actually on – and we've had on the greenfield side one or two programs finish up, such as potash in Ethiopia. But the main game, which is the main copper programs, are actually completely untouched in this exercise. And copper is the one product that really, from an exploration focus, we need to continue to add to the portfolio.
So we should think about them as being sustainable and not impacting the growth longer term?
Absolutely won't impact the capital plans.
Okay, thank you.
Thank you. And the next question comes from Richard Hatch of RBC. Richard, please go ahead.

Thanks very much. Just a question on your U.S. onshore. As you said (37:31) the past couple of periods, the OpEx has risen quite markedly, so is that likely to sustain or can we expect some improvement there? Thanks.

Richard, our target, starting at our two-year plan was really to take a very large resource that we bought, continue to invest in the most remunerative piece of that, which is the oil side, gradually expand the size of the business to where it can carry its own depreciation, that's kind of the immediate target for this year, get to an EBIT place where it carries all of its costs and then the next year strongly move into an EBIT positive territory.

We are on track and perhaps lost in the fog of figures is that there was quite a considerable inventory of drilled and completed wells. It's close to 100 at the period end which was waiting on infrastructure. So true to form, while Marc probably wouldn't like us to count the chickens before they're hatched, we're probably slightly ahead of targets in drilling and about on target for infrastructure, which means that we've put a little bit more drilling into inventory in that business which will manifest as increased production going forward.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you. And the next question comes from James Gurry of Credit Suisse. James, please go ahead.

Yes, thanks very much. It's James Gurry here from Credit Suisse. Thanks, guys. Just on the CapEx, the charts are indicating a pretty rapid drop-off over the next couple of years, especially when you look forward to 2015. So depending on commodity prices, there is scope to approve projects after this financial year. Can you just tell me how you're going to prioritize the potential projects including the low capital intense id (39:35) iron ore, the Spence Hypogene and of course the Jansen potash project?

Thank you very much. I've heard some of our peers talk about a top-down process in order to do this job on capital allocation and on cost reduction. Yes, our approach is 180-degrees different from that. For us, everything flows through great systems that create great transparency and data and flows bottom up.

We're in the middle of what I would call a stack and rank exercise in our capital and basically – it's not a single number exercise, so it's not only return, it is also risk, technical risk, geographical risk, product market risk, envelope of spread and so on, (40:31) but ultimately we get to a situation where bottom up stack and rank exercise gets done. We then overlay what we believe our balance sheet capacity is and our cash generation capacity is, and we cut the bubble (40:48) at the place where the two intersect.

I think last year, I said that the projects that had the highest return, that just didn't make it in was Cannington and probably Spence Hypogene on the copper side. I think Jimmy Wilson in iron ore has got every endeavor to – or every desire to present an iron ore project that will kick those projects out of the sequence.

So, once – until those numbers come in for the various projects and until we've done that stack and rank exercise, I can't tell you exactly what will be in and out, but I think Andrew will look forward to at our full year results, which is just after we've completed that assessment, to give you chapter and verse on what's in and what's out.
But you put your finger on the projects that are going to be working very hard to get in the sequence on the brownfield side, Cannington, Spence Hypogene and the Inner Harbour projects.
Great. Thanks.
Thank you. And your next question today comes from Abhi Shukla of Société Générale. Please go ahead.

Hi. I would like to ask two questions, if I may. First is an accounting kind of question, which is on your royalty-related taxation. Net of the $150 million one-time effect, it seems it's down about 10% year-on-year, even though your EBIT from the petroleum business is down like 20%. So, I'm just wondering if there is anything else which kept the stats artificially high in the current period apart from the $150 million that you have already announced.
Secondly, can you please...

Let me just answer that question first or not answer it by passing it to Graham. It's just, it's very, very difficult for us to answer multiple questions. Please, guys, if you could please just ask one question at a time, we'll try and endeavor as many as possible. So Graham, the accounting question?
Can I just hear the question again? It broke up a little bit.
Sorry, I couldn't hear you?
Could you just try and repeat the question? It broke up a little bit on our end.

Yes, sure. So, if I look at your royalties and look at tax, ignoring the $150 million revaluation effect, it's down 10% year-on-year, while your EBIT from petroleum, which is one of the key drivers of this tax, is down 20%. So, I'm just wondering if there is anything else which has moved dramatically to change this royalty-related tax.

Thanks.
